subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... what to ... bear, ... bit, and ... Concisely, as I understand it, we want to have something like Spanish has: (essentialy) phonemic, consistent spelling
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
>
> > If I'm not mistaken, the biggest problem facing us right now is
what to
> > do with mergers. I don't hear the difference between "beer" and
"bear,"
> > so how do I write this word? Do I write it as I hear it, but for more
> > formal writing look up its *pronounciation* (not spelling!) in a
> > standard dictionary? I think we have debated this issue quite a
bit, and
> > with good reason, considering it is our biggest obstacle. I'm open to
> > any suggestions on how to deal with mergers.
>
> Indeed, that is the central issue for any kind of writing or spelling
> reform for English-as-a-whole.
>

Concisely, as I understand it, we want to have something like Spanish
has: (essentialy) phonemic, consistent spelling and many accents
accommodated. Although obtaining exactly this seems impossible, if
we're clever we can get close and a judicious use of lexical sets will
now doubt help.
Much of what we are doing is discussed at:

http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/accents_spellingreform.htm

We have at least two big advantages over the article above:
-we are not limited to the Latin alphabet.
-we will tolerate some variation in spelling.


> In the case of the /r/ lexical sets, Read has decreed the use
> of Roe, and I think he's right: but we rhotic-speakers musn't
> underestimate the effort that will put on non-rhotics to
> remember where to write Roe and where not to.

And the rules are written such that when a non-rhotic speaker makes a
mistake, which will happen all the time, the word will still be
understandable. This works because the vowel used in the vowel+roe
pair has the same sound as when used outside of the pair. When
mistakes happen, "car" ends up sounding like "ka" which can still be
understood in context.
